tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Yahweh's name represents him. "Praise Yahweh" or "Praise him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This represents serving Yahweh in his temple.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Make sure that people can understand that the phrase "our God" refers to Yahweh.

tn.ref: for it is pleasant to do so
tn.text: "because we get pleasure from praising his name"
"Jacob" here refers to his descendants, the people of Israel. AT: "Yahweh has chosen Jacob's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The beginning of the sentence can be stated clearly. AT: "he has chosen Israel to be his possession" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: that our Lord is above all gods
tn.text: "I know that our Lord is above all gods." Being greater than something is spoken of as being above it. AT: "that our Lord is greater than all gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: bringing the wind out of his storehouse
tn.text: A storehouse is a place where things are kept for future use. This imagery shows God's power to control the wind. AT: "causing the wind to blow by his power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These two words mean basically the same thing and refer to the miraculous troubles that God had caused in Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The psalmist speaks as if the people of Egypt were listening to him. AT: "among you people of Egypt" or "among the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
These are the names of two men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: He gave us their land as an inheritance
tn.text: God's gift of the land to the Israelites is spoken of as if it were inheritance from father to son. AT: "He gave us their land to have forever" or "He gave us their land to be ours forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
His name here represents his fame or reputation. AT: "Your fame" or "Your reputation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Those who make them are like them
tn.text: Being ignorant and powerless is spoken of as being like idols, which cannot speak, see, hear, or breathe. AT: "Those who make them are stupid and powerless like their idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: as is everyone who trusts in them
tn.text: "and so are those who trust in the idols"
God is spoken of as if he lived in Jerusalem because the temple where the Israelites worshiped him was there. AT: "he whose temple is in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
